head.title: Epistle to a Black-smith.11 First published in Poetical Essays (1788), pp. 188-190. The addressee of this poem, an unidentified black-smith poet in Ayr, is not the same as the “William Reid, Blacksmith,” for whose comedy The Heroine performed in Dumfries Turnbull would write a theatrical prologue, which he eventually published in the Columbian Herald and New Daily Advertiser [Charleston, SC] (March 26, 1796).

lg.l: Dear Sir, if my unnotic’d name,
Not yet proclaim’d by trump of fame,
Has reach’d your lugs,22 n. ears. then swith33 adv. rapidly, quickly. attend,
This essay of a Bard unkend.
An honest man, lang may he thrive,
(And ilka honest man alive)
As we were wheeling round the bicker,44 n. wooden drinking cup; in modern Scottish, vessels made of wooden staves for holding porridge.
Tald me that he was unco55 adj. unknown, unfamiliar, strange. sicker
A’ this braid shire, and other three,
Contain’d na sic a chiel as thee;
That ye, tho’ thumpin at the study,
Cou’d mak a verse on ony body,
In nipping, slie, satiric stile,
We’ teeth as sharp as ony file.
Bedeen, I gat upo’ my shanks,
And gae the carle routh o’ thanks,
And sware an aith, e’en b’ my sang,
“His metal I shall try e’er lang;
And then I’ll tell ye gif the chiel
Be useless ir’n or temper’d steel.”
It shaws I hae but little gumption,
Tho’ no way scanty o’ presumption,
To bourd wi’ ane of sic engine,
And parts sae far exceeding mine;
For, a’ that ken ye can declare,
Your match is scarce in ony where,
But my impatience may excuse me,
Lest ye should for a dult abuse me.
O wad my scanty purse but spare,
That I might tak a jaunt to Ayr,66 Coastal town situated in western Scotland on the mouth of the River Ayr near Robert Burns’s birthplace.
Ae night wi’ thee to sing and roar,
And set auld care ahint the door;
Then we shou’d hae a merry bout,
And no sit dumb nor yet cast out.
But, lest that we shou’d ne’er forgether,
To get a crack wi’ ane anither,
My earnest prayer ay shall be,
For routh o’ coals, and ir’n to thee;
That ye may lang be hale and canty,
And ding that cursed carle want ay;
That ye may ne’er be scant o’ brass,
To synd the spark that’s I’ yer hause;
That, as ye blaw your smithy fire,
Apollo77 God of medicine, music, especially the lyre, archery and prophecy. may your wit inspire,
To gar your easy flowing rhyme,
Just like alternate hammers chime;
And, that your mind be ne’er perplex’d,
But firm as ony anvil fix’d;
That, as your gauds of ir’n ye bow,
Your enemies may yield to you;

May, by the fatal sisters three,88 The fates. Cf. the weird sisters in Shakespeare’s Macbeth (1606) and Thomas Gray “The Fatal Sisters. An Ode.” in Thomas Gray and William Collins: Poetical Works, ed. Roger Lonsdale (Oxford and New York: Oxford UP, 1977), p. 62.
Thy chain of life extended be,
Till unto langest life thy dust,
Stand proof against the teeth of rust;
And, when grim Death, wi’ fatal dart,
Shall gar they saul and body part,
May this thy Epitaph be made,
“Here Vulcan99 God of fire. lies, a matchless Blade."
